pullRequest.body:
co-authored by: @erdOne 

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [b53b201eef](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/21829/commits/b53b201eef5cc2f6719377917081ed74da4323a1)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.TensorProduct.HomTensor` (new file)|1306|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Module.Hom.Tensor:`
`+ comm_sqaure3:`
`+ comm_square2:`
`+ comm_square2_apply`
`+ comm_square3_apply`
`+ comm_square4:`
`+ homTensorHomMap_bij:`
`+ homTensorHomMap_inj`
`+ homTensorHomMap_surj:`
`+ inclusion1`
`+ projection1`
`+ projection2_inclusion2`
`+ projection2_inclusion2_apply`
`+ projection_inlusion1`
`+ tensor_inclusion1`
`+ tensor_inclusion1_inj:`
`+ tensor_inclusion1_projection1`
`+ tensor_inclusion1_projection1_apply`
`+ tensor_inclusion2`
`+ tensor_inclusion2_inj`
`+ tensor_projection1`
`+ tensor_projection2`
`+ tensor_projection2_inclusion2`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
You probably shouldn't start wit this. You should start with an arbitrary free module and these splittings. And specialize to finite projective modules in the ned.
but I thought the whole file is about finite projective modules?
Yes but this should work for arbitrary splittings of projective modules, not only the one obtained by choice.

```suggestion
This file proves that for `M` and `N` finitely generated projective
```

```suggestion
modules over a commutative ring `R`, the tensor product of the hom module
```

```suggestion
from `M` to `P` and the one from `N` to `Q` for `P`, `Q` being arbitrary
```

I don't think you can make a definition in the root namespace with a name like that. If you `open LinearMap` then `lcomp _ _ f0` is shorter than `inclusion1 R M P M' f0` anyway so this "abbreviation" is actually making things longer?

```suggestion
  TensorProduct.map (f0.lcomp R P) (f0'.lcomp R Q)
```
is shorter. Why not put this abbrev in some `TensorProduct` namespace and give it a better name? It has nothing to do with inclusions as far as I can see.
I think these names are not suitable for mathlib. The naming convention doesn't say anything about 1's. Why can't we just follow the naming convention with these lemmas?

pullRequest.title: feat(LinearAlgebra/TensorProduct/HomTensor): Add TensorProduct of Hom-modules
